newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Regent presses Pioneer on share rating.
newsitem.headline: Regent presses Pioneer on share rating.

text.p: Regent Fund Management Ltd's bid to shake up Pioneer Industries International (Holdings) Ltd may come to a head at a special general meeting on Tuesday, when Pioneer's management will be asked to take action to improve its share performance.

Regent, the Regent Pacific Group unit known as an unusually aggressive investor, said Pioneer is trading at a 59-percent discount to net asset value and drastic steps must be taken to improve share performance.
Those steps could include selling its prime asset, a sizeable stake in Bangkok Bank Ltd, Thailand's biggest bank.
"We're basically asking the company to do a better job of managing the company," Regent chairman Peter Everington told reporters on Thursday.
The fund acquired 13.64 percent of Pioneer last November.
Regent estimates Pioneer's net asset value at HK$12.46 per share after tax. Pioneer shares closed at HK$5.90 on Thursday, valuing the company at HK$1.81 billion.
Pioneer's 3.77-percent stake in Bangkok Bank is valued at HK$2.4 billion at current market price.

Regent also claimed Pioneer's stake in Bangkok Bank is actually much greater than the company has admitted due to another 6.5 million foreign shares held through a 49-percent stake in a Liberian company called Central Asia Ltd.
This increases Pioneer's stake in Bangkok Bank to 4.4 percent, including the Central Asia holding.
"They are not informing shareholders of what is there," Everington said.

Pioneer officials were not available to respond to Regent's charges. Media reports indicate that Pioneer has repeatedly stated in public that its holding in Bangkok Bank is "slightly less than five percent."
Pioneer has also said publicly that it considers Regent's move as hostile, and it intends to send a letter to shareholders urging them to vote against the resolutions.
Regent wants to see some action on Tuesday at a Pioneer special general meeting, otherwise it will introduce another 13 directors to Pioneer's 11-member board of directors.

"We are only doing so because we anticipate the company is reluctant to take action," said Everington. "We have no desire to run Pioneer. We have no desire to take it over. What we are trying to do is persuade management to run the company better."
